001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab;
002
003import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
004import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.MathTools;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.BitConversion;
006
007import java.util.Random;
008
009/**
010 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
011 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
012 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
013 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
014 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
015 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components (though because of
016 * what colorful does, A and B should be multiplied by 2).
017 * <br>
018 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
019 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
020 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
021 */
022public class ColorTools {
023        /**
024         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
025         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
026         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). L should be
027         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
028         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
029         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
030         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
031         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
032         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
033         * <br>
034         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
035         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
036         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
037         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
038         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
039         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
040         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
041         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
042         *
043         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
044         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
045         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
046         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
047         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
048         */
049        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
050                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
051                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
052        }
053
054
055        /**
056         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
057         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. It
058         * correctly returns negative results when given negative inputs.
059         * <br>
060         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
061         * distributed between -512 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
062         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
063         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
064         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
065         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
066         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
067         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
068         * <br>
069         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
070         * @param x any finite float to find the cube root of
071         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
072         */
073        private static float cbrt(float x) {
074                int ix = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(x);
075                final int sign = ix & 0x80000000;
076                ix &= 0x7FFFFFFF;
077                final float x0 = x;
078                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
079                ix += (ix>>>4);
080                ix = ix + (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0 | sign;
081                x  = BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(ix);
082                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
083                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
084                return x;
085        }
086
087        /**
088         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
089         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
090         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
091         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
092         */
093        private static float cube(final float x) {
094                return x * x * x;
095        }
096
097        /**
098         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
099         * Really just {@code component * component}.
100         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
101         * @return a linear version of component
102         */
103        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
104                return component * component;
105        }
106
107        /**
108         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
109         * Really just gets the square root of component, as a float.
110         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
111         * @return a non-linear version of component
112         */
113        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
114                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
115        }
116
117
118        /**
119         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
120         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
121         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
122         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
123         */
124        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
125        {
126                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
127                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
128                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
129                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
130                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
131                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
132                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
133                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
134                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
135                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
136                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
137        }
138
139        /**
140         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
141         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
142         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
143         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
144         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
145         */
146        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
147        {
148                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
149                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
150                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
151                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
152                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
153                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
154                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
155                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
156                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
157                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
158                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
159        }
160
161        /**
162         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
163         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
164         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
165         */
166        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
167                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
168                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
169                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
170
171                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
172                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
173                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
174
175                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
176                                      MathTools.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
177                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
178                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
179                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
180        }
181
182        /**
183         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
184         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
185         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
186         */
187        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
188                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
189                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
190                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
191                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
192                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
193                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
194                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
195                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
196                                          MathTools.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
197                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
198                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
199                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
200        }
201
202        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
203        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
204        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
205        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
206
207        /**
208         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
209         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
210         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
211         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
212         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
213         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
214         */
215        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
216                r = forwardGamma(r);
217                g = forwardGamma(g);
218                b = forwardGamma(b);
219                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
220                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
221                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
222                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
223                                          MathTools.clamp((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0, 255)
224                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.9889992500f * l - 1.2142961000f * m + 0.2252968500f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 8
225                                                | MathTools.clamp((int)((0.0129520185f * l + 0.3913858800f * m - 0.4043378800f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0, 255) << 16
226                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
227        }
228
229        /**
230         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
231         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
232         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
233         */
234        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
235        {
236                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
237                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
238                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
239                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
240                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
241                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
242                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
243                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
244        }
245
246        /**
247         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
248         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
249         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
250         */
251        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
252        {
253                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
254                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
255                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
256                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
257                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
258                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
259                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
260                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
261        }
262
263        /**
264         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
265         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
266         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
267         */
268        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
269        {
270                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
271                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
272                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
273                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
274                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
275                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
276                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
277                return (int)(reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f)) * 255.999f);
278        }
279
280        /**
281         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
282         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
283         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
284         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
285         */
286        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
287        {
288                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
289        }
290
291        /**
292         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
293         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
294         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
295         */
296        public static float red(final float encoded)
297        {
298                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
299                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
300                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
301                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
302                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
303                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
304                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
305                return reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
306        }
307
308        /**
309         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
310         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
311         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
312         */
313        public static float green(final float encoded)
314        {
315                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
316                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
317                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
318                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
319                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
320                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
321                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
322                return reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
323        }
324
325        /**
326         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
327         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
328         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
329         */
330        public static float blue(final float encoded)
331        {
332                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
333                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
334                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
335                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
336                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
337                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
338                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
339                return reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
340        }
341
342        /**
343         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
344         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
345         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
346         */
347        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
348        {
349                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
350        }
351
352        /**
353         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
354         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
355         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
356         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
357         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
358         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
359         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
360         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
361         *
362         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
363         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
364         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
365         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
366         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
367         */
368        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
369                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
370                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
371                } else {
372                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
373                }
374        }
375
376        /**
377         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
378         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
379         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
380         */
381        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
382                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
383                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
384                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
385                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
386                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
387                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
388                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
389                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
390                final float r = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
391                final float g = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
392                final float b = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
393                float x, y, w;
394                if(g < b) {
395                        x = b;
396                        y = g;
397                }
398                else {
399                        x = g;
400                        y = b;
401                }
402                if(r < x) {
403                        w = r;
404                }
405                else {
406                        w = x;
407                        x = r;
408                }
409                return x - Math.min(w, y);
410//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
411//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
412//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
413        }
414
415        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
416                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
417                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
418                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
419                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
420                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
421                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
422                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
423                final float r = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
424                final float g = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
425                final float b = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
426                float x, y, w;
427                if(g < b) {
428                        x = b;
429                        y = g;
430                }
431                else {
432                        x = g;
433                        y = b;
434                }
435                if(r < x) {
436                        w = r;
437                }
438                else {
439                        w = x;
440                        x = r;
441                }
442                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
443                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
444        }
445
446        /**
447         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
448         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
449         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
450         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
451         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
452         */
453        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
454                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
455                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
456                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
457                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
458                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
459                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
460                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
461                final float r = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
462                final float g = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
463                final float b = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
464                float x, y, z, w;
465                if(g < b) {
466                        x = b;
467                        y = g;
468                        z = -1f;
469                        w = 2f / 3f;
470                }
471                else {
472                        x = g;
473                        y = b;
474                        z = 0f;
475                        w = -1f / 3f;
476                }
477                if(r < x) {
478                        z = w;
479                        w = r;
480                }
481                else {
482                        w = x;
483                        x = r;
484                }
485                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
486                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
487        }
488
489        /**
490         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
491         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
492         *
493         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
494         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
495         */
496        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
497        {
498                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
499        }
500
501        /**
502         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
503         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
504         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
505         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
506         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
507         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
508         */
509        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
510        {
511                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
516         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
517         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
518         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
519         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
520         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
521         */
522        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
523        {
524                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
525        }
526
527        /**
528         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, value, and
529         * opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Takes floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue,
530         * saturation, value, and opacity; these can be between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or
531         * encoded color. The float is
532         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
533         * value, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
534         * <br>
535         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
536         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
537         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
538         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
539         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
540         *
541         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
542         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
543         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
544         * @param value      -1f to 1f, the value/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
545         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
546         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
547         */
548        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float value, float opacity) {
549                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
550                final float L = MathTools.clamp(value + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f, 1f);
551                opacity = MathTools.clamp(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f, 1f);
552                if (L <= 0.001f)
553                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
554                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
555                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
556                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
557                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
558                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
559                final float r = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f, 1f));
560                final float g = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f, 1f));
561                final float b = reverseGamma(MathTools.clamp(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f, 1f));
562                float x, y, z, w;
563                if(g < b) {
564                        x = b;
565                        y = g;
566                        z = -1f;
567                        w = 2f / 3f;
568                }
569                else {
570                        x = g;
571                        y = b;
572                        z = 0f;
573                        w = -1f / 3f;
574                }
575                if(r < x) {
576                        z = w;
577                        w = r;
578                }
579                else {
580                        w = x;
581                        x = r;
582                }
583                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
584                float hue2 = Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
585                float sat2 = (x - L) / (Math.min(L, 1f - L) + 1e-10f);
586                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue2 + hue + 1 - (int)(hue2 + hue + 1), MathTools.clamp(saturation + sat2, 0f, 1f), L, opacity));
587        }
588
589        /**
590         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
591         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
592         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
593         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
594         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
595         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
596         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
597         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
598         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
599         */
600        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
601                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
602                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
603        }
604
605        /**
606         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
607         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
608         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
609         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
610         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
611         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
612         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
613         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
614         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
615         */
616        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
617                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
618                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
619        }
620
621        /**
622         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
623         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
624         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
625         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
626         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
627         * alpha and L of start as-is.
628         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
629         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
630         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
631         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
632         */
633        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
634                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
635                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
636        }
637
638        /**
639         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
640         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
641         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
642         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
643         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
644         * L of start as-is.
645         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
646         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
647         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
648         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
649         */
650        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
651                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
652                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
653        }
654
655        /**
656         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
657         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
658         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
659         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
660         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
661         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
662         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
663         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
664         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
665         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
666         */
667        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
668                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
669                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
670        }
671
672        /**
673         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
674         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
675         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
676         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
677         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
678         * alpha and L of start as-is.
679         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
680         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
681         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
682         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
683         */
684        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
685                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
686                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
687        }
688
689        /**
690         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
691         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
692         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
693         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
694         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
695         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
696         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
697         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
698         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
699         */
700        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
701                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
702                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
703        }
704
705        /**
706         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
707         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
708         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
709         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
710         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
711         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
712         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
713         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
714         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
715         */
716        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
717                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
718                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
719        }
720
721        /**
722         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
723         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
724         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
725         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
726         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
727         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
728         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
729         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
730         */
731        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
732                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
733                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
734                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
735                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
736                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
737        }
738
739        /**
740         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
741         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
742         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only A and B, but higher values for
743         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
744         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change L somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
745         * then L won't change; alpha never changes.
746         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
747         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
748         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
749         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
750         */
751        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
752                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
753                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
754                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
755                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
756                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
757        }
758
759
760        /**
761         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
762         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
763         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
764         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
765         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
766         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
767         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
768         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
769         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
770         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
771         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
772         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
773         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
774         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
775         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
776         */
777        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
778        {
779                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
780                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
781                                L = (bits & 0xff),
782                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
783                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
784                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
785                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
786                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
787                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
788                        return mainColor;
789                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
790        }
791
792        /**
793         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
794         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
795         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
796         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
797         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
798         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
799         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
800         */
801        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
802                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
803                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
804                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
805                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
806                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
807                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
808                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
809        }
810
811        /**
812         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
813         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
814         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
815         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
816         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
817         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
818         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
819         * but only internally for measuring distance).
820         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
821         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
822         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
823         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
824         */
825        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
826                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
827                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
828                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
829                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
830                final float limit = variance * variance;
831                float dist, x, y, z;
832                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
833                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
834                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
835                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
836                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
837                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
838                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
839                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
840                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
841                }
842                return color;
843        }
844
845        /**
846         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
847         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
848         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
849         */
850        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
851        {
852                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
853                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
854                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
855                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
856                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
857                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
858                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
859
860                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
861                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
862                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
863                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
864                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
865                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
866        }
867        /**
868         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
869         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
870         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
871         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
872         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
873         */
874        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
875        {
876                A = (A - 0.5f) * 2f;
877                B = (B - 0.5f) * 2f;
878                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
879                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
880                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
881
882                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
883//              if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) {
884//                      System.out.println("r out of gamut: " + r);
885//                      return false;
886//              }
887                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
888                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
889//              if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) {
890//                      System.out.println("g out of gamut: " + g);
891//                      return false;
892//              }
893                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
894                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
895//              if(b < 0f || b > 1.0f) {
896//                      System.out.println("b out of gamut: " + b);
897//                      return false;
898//              }
899//              return true;
900                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
901        }
902
903        /**
904         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
905         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
906         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
907         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
908         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
909         */
910        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
911                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
912                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
913                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
914                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
915                float L2 = L, A2 = A, B2 = B;
916                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
917                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
918                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
919                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
920
921                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
922                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
923                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
924                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
925                                break;
926                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
927                        L2 = MathTools.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
928                        A2 = MathTools.lerp(0, A, progress);
929                        B2 = MathTools.lerp(0, B, progress);
930                }
931                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
932        }
933
934        /**
935         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
936         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
937         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
938         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
939         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
940         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
941         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
942         */
943        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
944                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
945        }
946        /**
947         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
948         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
949         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
950         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
951         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
952         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
953         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
954         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
955         */
956        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
957                float L2 = L = MathTools.clamp(L, 0f, 1f);
958                float A2 = A = MathTools.clamp((A - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
959                float B2 = B = MathTools.clamp((B - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f, 1f);
960                alpha = MathTools.clamp(alpha, 0f, 1f);
961                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
962                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
963                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
964                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
965
966                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
967                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
968                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
969                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
970                                break;
971                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
972                        L2 = MathTools.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
973                        A2 = MathTools.lerp(0, A, progress);
974                        B2 = MathTools.lerp(0, B, progress);
975                }
976                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
977        }
978
979        /**
980         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
981         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like
982         * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.support.LaserRandom})
983         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
984         */
985        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
986                float L = random.nextFloat();
987                float A = random.nextFloat();
988                float B = random.nextFloat();
989                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
990                        L = random.nextFloat();
991                        A = random.nextFloat();
992                        B = random.nextFloat();
993                }
994                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
995        }
996}
